Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s 1968 Night of the Living Dead spawned remakes, sequels and even spin-off’s for decades. While popular theatrical films kept the genre alive for a long time, it was the advent of reality television that almost killed it dead.

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick themselves up, put down roots, start anew, thrive, succeed—in other words, a land of immigrants and opportunity. And one where the taxpayers pay for everything.

The Dutch — a place that values privileged educations, subsidizes foreign workers into top positions

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, but the crowning descision made by director Vincent Ward is the complete lack of subtitles for the entire 1 hour and 40 minute film! Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by comparison to more recent Disney fairy tales, thanks to computer graphics. The biggest mistake to me is that the picture was pretty much devoid of magic. The good points are a few catchy songs, and certain landscapes looking like a fantasy mural found in certain churches in the Middle Ages.<|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|>

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy fliers have long since left Planet Earth, for adventures across the Universe in their space ships, along with their pets, the felines. A few heavily armed groups survive on the Earth continent of Africa. Yet, the wild feral cats are affected by the depleted and dying radioactive pollen.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is going to score big time with martial arts aficionados, just as long you do not mind a low budget and if you bother watch TV series like Walker, Texas Ranger and it is ok if you greatly enjoyed a sequel to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.
